chapter.title: Planning can be challenging for individuals with LD
chapter.content:
Planning can be challenging for individuals with LD

Planning is connected to having realistic goals and aspirations. Planning means that a person believes that what he or she does can make a difference. For some individuals with LD, planning can be challenging because it taps into specific areas of weakness. For others, planning can get their creative juices flowing.

Elements of planning include:

  • setting goals and determining steps to meet them;
  • expecting positive results;
  • embracing your creativity; and
  • practicing.

chapter.title: Planning questions a self-determined person can answer
chapter.content:
Planning questions a self-determined person can answer

A self-determined person can answer these questions:

  • What are my long-term and short-term goals?
  • Can I plan in a way that uses my strengths?
  • Once I make a plan, can I follow it?
  • Can I anticipate positive and negative outcomes?
  • Do I involve others who can support me when I plan?

Please take a moment to reflect upon your own experiences with planning. What can make planning difficult?

Click the forward arrow when you are ready to proceed.

chapter.title: Situations that can make planning difficult
chapter.content:
Situations that can make planning difficult

Although many answers apply, some examples of situations that can make planning difficult include:

  • when you don’t know what to expect;
  • when you feel overwhelmed; and
  • when you can’t anticipate how others will react.

chapter.title: Ideas for supporting individuals with LD to make plans
chapter.content:
Ideas for supporting individuals with LD to make plans

While there are many skills and supports for good planning, some examples are:

  • being able to break down acts into a step-by-step process
  • being able to consider how others will act and react; and
  • access to resources.

Planning is particularly important for individuals with LD, as it can help them to:

  • accommodate functional challenges; and
  • overcome specific areas of weakness.

When you have finished recording your ideas, click the forward arrow to proceed.

chapter.title: Ideas for supporting individuals with LD plan effectively
chapter.content:
Ideas for supporting individuals with LD plan effectively

Some ideas for supporting individuals with LD to plan effectively include:

  • Support them in setting short- and long-term goals (e.g., inform individuals of the objective for a class or tutoring session and have them set a goal for their learning for that session), as well as mid-range goals (e.g., How many vocabulary words do you want to learn this month?).
  • Once goals are set, involve the individuals in planning how to accomplish an assigned task, asking them to identify one or more strategies they can use.
  • Ask individuals to evaluate the effectiveness of a class and tutoring session and set a plan for the next session.

Take a moment to compare your ideas with those listed.
